awd_titl_txt: IRES Track I: Algorithms and Software for SUpercomputers with emerging aRchitEctures (ASSURE)
awd_abstract_narration:
Supercomputers enable researchers to push the boundaries of science and find innovative approaches to complex problems. From improving advanced manufacturing with modeling and simulation to understanding earth systems and weather with greater precision, harnessing the data revolution and applying data to understand life processes, supercomputers are essential to human advancement.  HPC (High Performing Computer) systems of the future will likely be very different from those of today. Emerging architectures can have a tremendous impact on the development of software, methods and models that can take advantage of these new features resulting in speed up and improvement in the accuracy of calculations. Early adoption of these emerging technologies to take advantage of special features is key to remaining competitive in the global economy. The goal of this IRES site is to engage PhD. students in research learning experiences that increase their capacity to conduct research on supercomputing systems, (including those with classical and emerging architectures), and their exposure to international collaborative research.

This IRES, called ASSURE, aims to enhance the capabilities of US graduate students to develop Algorithms and Software in key scientific disciplines that benefit from Supercomputers and emerging aRchitEctures (ASSURE). The program focuses on equipping students to conduct research on one of the fastest supercomputers in the world, Sunway Taihulight, housed in Wuxi China, which has a unique architecture. ASSURE achieves this goal by: (i) training students to utilize unique international large-scale systems; (ii) engaging students in high quality collaborative research in four key areas of computational and data science utilizing these systems; and (iii) exposing students to international large-scale research environments that prepare them with cultural and professional skills required to occupy international leadership roles. Specifically, IRES students at this site will conduct research at two locations in China: The National Supercomputing Center (NSCC) in Wuxi China and the University of Tsinghua and the East China Normal University.

The ASSURE site is open to US Ph.D. students with an interest in computational and data science in the areas of earth systems, drug design, advanced manufacturing, big data and machine learning. Specifically, US citizens or permanent residents, including women and students from underrepresented populations in international STEM research, are invited to participate.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The work of this IRES site, Algorithms & Software for Supercomputers with Emerging Architectures (ASSURE), prepared graduate students for careers in computational and data science through a variety of short (3 months) and medium-term (9-12 month) internships with leading researchers at national supercomputing centers in China, Japan and Germany. These internships were designed to:

 

  • Develop and strengthen exchanges between U.S. researchers and leading international research groups who utilize advanced computing to answer questions in Earth & Weather Systems, Life Sciences and Big Data;

  • Increase students’ advanced computing knowledge and understanding of how emerging computing architectures and software tools can be applied to answer questions within specific disciplines;

  • Increase students’ ability to work more collaboratively across and within diverse cultural contexts and structures;

  • Assist students in clarifying their research and career interests;

 

Through a series of meetings, selected graduate students, working under the guidance of their U.S. advisors, initiate research collaborations with computational groups at international supercomputing sites. Student participants meet, via frequent  zoom meetings, with their international research group and advisor over the space of a few weeks to learn more about their research problem and get up to speed with the team. Technical personnel from the host group enable students to access the group's supercomputer and begin work. Finally, students travel to their hosts to spend a few weeks working face-to-face with the team, exploring the culture through close interactions with international team members and other leading researchers and sightseeing excursions. After several months, students prepare reports of their findings. Several have gone on to publish at conferences and in peer-reviewed journals.

 

The project suffered several setbacks due to the COVID-19 pandemic and its format evolved to accommodate the needs of researchers. Beginning as a 3-month in-person Summer internship in 2019, it transformed from a 12-month fully in-person or fully virtual internship in 2022 to a 9-month hybrid internship in 2023, with participants spending between 2 weeks - 3 months at the international host site. The most productive periods were those where students spent the greatest time at the host site and (predictably) where students felt most engaged in the life of their host research groups.

 

In total approximately 20 students applied to the program and nine (1 female, 5 male and 3 non-binary) were selected to participate from five universities across the U.S. Students hailed from Phd programs in social sciences, engineering, biological, physical and computational sciences. In addition to scientific products - 2 peer-reviewed journal articles and 2 conference poster presentations - program participants identified several outcomes including: 

  1. developing close, productive interactions within the international research team, with an expressed belief that these interactions would become significant in their careers as scientists; 

  2. increased interest and knowledge of several fundamental (theory) aspects of their field as a result of their research engagement;

  3. significant improvement in their computational skills, widened knowledge of high-performance computing, generating research ideas and informing their ideas about data ethics; 

  4. growth in their ability to collaborate, learn from and communicate with experts outside their discipline to drive their project forward; resulting in them becoming more independent researchers; and finally

  5. building personal and professional strengths such as thriving in unfamiliar situations and conflict management; and broadening their understanding of different cultures and research environments.
